description:
kanbusr should automatically detect whether stdout is a TTY (terminal) and adjust its output accordingly:

When stdout IS a TTY (interactive terminal):
- Display full ANSI colors for better readability
- Use rich formatting with colored status indicators, priority levels, etc.

When stdout is NOT a TTY (piped, redirected, or captured):
- Automatically disable all ANSI color codes
- Output plain text that's safe for parsing, logging, or piping to other commands
- No need for users to specify --porcelain flag manually

Implementation approach:
- Use Rust's std::io::IsTerminal trait or atty/is-terminal crate
- Check isatty(stdout) at startup
- Set a global or context flag for color output
- Apply this flag to all formatting code

This is standard behavior for CLI tools (ls, grep, git, cargo, etc.) and ensures kanbusr plays nicely with scripts, CI/CD pipelines, and tools like Claude Code that capture command output.
title: kanbusr should auto-detect TTY and disable colors in non-interactive mode

description:
Add CLI commands and backend wiring to feature/focus a specific issue on the board via realtime messaging, including auto-focus on issue creation and agent-invoked focus.

## Architecture Overview

The current Kanbus architecture has a 15-second polling-based SSE system. This epic implements a real-time notification system using broadcast channels that reduces latency from 15 seconds to <100ms.

Key insight: Once we build the socket-based notification infrastructure for the focus feature, we can extend it to ALL CRUD operations (create, update, delete), enabling the entire board to update with much lower latency.

## Implementation Phases

### Phase 1: Real-time Notification Infrastructure
- Create notification_events.rs with NotificationEvent enum (IssueCreated, IssueUpdated, IssueDeleted, IssueFocused)
- Extend console_local.rs with broadcast::channel for notifications
- Create notification_publisher.rs to POST events to console server
- Add SSE endpoint /api/events/realtime for streaming notifications

### Phase 2: Hook CRUD Operations (see sub-tasks)
- Hook issue_creation.rs, issue_update.rs, issue_delete.rs
- Hook issue_comment.rs, dependencies.rs
- Hook beads_write.rs for beads compatibility mode

### Phase 3: Implement Focus Command
- Add ConsoleCommands::Focus in cli.rs
- Create focus handler that validates issue and publishes IssueFocused event
- Add --focus flag to kbs create command for auto-focus on creation
- Enable agents to invoke focus command

### Phase 4: Frontend Integration
- Add subscribeToNotifications() in api/client.ts
- Handle notification events in App.tsx (focus, create, update, delete)
- Add GSAP animations for visual feedback (see tskl-e7j.7)

### Phase 5: Console Server Endpoints
- POST /api/notifications - Receives events from CLI
- GET /api/events/realtime - SSE stream for frontend
- Use broadcast channel pattern like telemetry system

## Critical Files

Backend:
- rust/src/bin/console_local.rs - Console server
- rust/src/notification_events.rs (NEW)
- rust/src/notification_publisher.rs (NEW)
- rust/src/cli.rs - Add focus command

Frontend:
- apps/console/src/api/client.ts
- apps/console/src/App.tsx
- apps/console/src/components/IssueCard.tsx

## Architecture Benefits

1. Latency: 15 seconds  <100ms for all operations
2. User Experience: Immediate feedback on all actions
3. Agent Collaboration: Agents can direct human attention via focus
4. Scalability: Broadcast channel supports multiple subscribers
5. Backward Compatibility: Existing 15-second polling remains as fallback
6. Extensibility: Easy to add new event types

## Technical Considerations

- Notification failures should not block CRUD operations
- Broadcast channel buffer (256) prevents memory bloat
- SSE connection auto-reconnects on failure
- Event payload kept small (<5KB)
- Console server binds to localhost only

comments.text: Starting research on MiniJinja compatibility with Jinja2 to inform wiki templating. Will capture findings and implications for Rust/Python parity.

comments.author: Ryan Alyn Porter
comments.text: Research summary: MiniJinja aims to stay close to Jinja2 and supports core Jinja2 features like inheritance, filters, and expression evaluation (per project docs). It does not chase full compatibility at all costs; some templates that look valid in Jinja2 will not render in MiniJinja, but cross-compatible templates are possible. MiniJinja syntax matches Jinja2 in many areas but has documented differences, e.g., line statement/comment whitespace behavior differs from Jinja2 and requires custom_syntax, and inline if without else returns a silent undefined. Also, template imports behave differently: imports are not cached and only exported variables/macros are available. Implication for Taskulus wiki: keep template feature set small and explicitly documented, avoid reliance on Jinja2-only edge cases (line statements whitespace, import side effects), and build specs around the shared subset.

comments.text:
Feature: Validation enforcement

Scenario: Create rejects invalid issue types
Given a Kanbus project with default configuration
When I run "kanbus create Bad Type --type invalid"
Then the command should fail with exit code 1
And stderr should contain "unknown issue type"

Scenario: Create rejects invalid parent-child relationships
Given a Kanbus project with default configuration
And an issue "kanbus-epic01" exists of type "epic"
When I run "kanbus create Bad Parent --type epic --parent kanbus-epic01"
Then the command should fail with exit code 1
And stderr should contain "invalid parent-child relationship"

Scenario: Update rejects invalid status transitions
Given a Kanbus project with default configuration
And an issue "kanbus-test01" of type "task" with status "open"
When I run "kanbus update kanbus-test01 --status blocked"
Then the command should fail with exit code 1
And stderr should contain "invalid transition"

Scenario: Bypass validation with --no-validate
Given a Kanbus project with default configuration
And an issue "kanbus-epic01" exists of type "epic"
When I run "kanbus create Bad Parent --type epic --parent kanbus-epic01 --no-validate"
Then the command should succeed

Hook create_issue() and create_beads_issue() to publish NotificationEvent::IssueCreated. Ensure frontend receives and displays new issues immediately (<100ms latency).

## Implementation Details

### Files to Modify
- rust/src/issue_creation.rs (after write_issue_to_file() succeeds, ~line 140)
- rust/src/beads_write.rs::create_beads_issue() (after append_record(), line 19)

### Pattern
```rust
// After successful creation
publish_notification(NotificationEvent::IssueCreated {
    issue_id: issue.id.clone(),
    issue_data: issue.clone(),
})?;
```

### Testing
1. Start console server: kbs console snapshot --serve

### Dependencies

description:
Enable complete programmatic control of the console UI through CLI commands using the real-time notification system. This extends the socket+SSE architecture from tskl-e7j to support all UI actions: view switching, search, filtering, settings, detail panel control, and more. This enables agents and scripts to drive the UI remotely.

Architecture:
- Reuse existing notification infrastructure from tskl-e7j
- CLI commands publish UI control events via Unix socket
- Console server broadcasts events via SSE to frontend
- Frontend updates state in response to events

Benefits:
1. Agent Integration: Agents can control the UI to guide human attention
2. Testing: Automated UI state verification
3. Scripting: Batch UI operations
4. Remote Control: Drive UI from external tools
5. Consistency: All UI actions accessible via both GUI and CLI
title: Programmatic UI Control via CLI Commands

description:
Make the console server a stateful orchestrator that pushes URL routes to connected browser clients. CLI commands (focus, search, view) flow through the server, which constructs a URL encoding the desired UI state and pushes it to all clients via SSE. The frontend navigates to whatever URL it receives. The URL is the universal state contract -- same mechanism works for local server (SSE), cloud (WebSocket), or pasting a link.

No backwards-compatibility logic. This is the only way it works.

Architecture:
- Server pushes URL routes to clients via SSE (e.g., /issues/tskl-abc?focused=tskl-abc&comment=8ea9cd)
- All UI state is URL-addressable: view mode (path), focused issue (query param), search (query param), comment (query param)
- AppState holds a ConsoleUiState cache of the last-pushed route (for CLI query commands)
- State persists to .kanbus/.cache/console_state.json across server restarts
- CLI query commands (kbs console status, get focus, get view, get search) read from the cache
- New SSE subscribers receive the last-pushed route on connect

Stories:
1. Server maintains canonical UI state in memory (cache of last-pushed route)
2. State persists to .kanbus/.cache/console_state.json across restarts
3. kbs console status -- prints full state summary
4. kbs console get focus -- prints focused issue ID or none
5. kbs console get view -- prints current view mode or none
6. kbs console get search -- prints active search query
7. All UI state is URL-addressable (search, focus, view mode in the URL)
8. New browser tabs receive last-pushed route on connect
9. Deep link to specific comment within an issue
title: Organize and expand CLI commands for UI state inspection and control

description:
Given the console server is running

When a CLI command changes the focused issue, view mode, or search query
Then the server constructs a URL route encoding the full desired UI state
And pushes that route to all connected clients via SSE
And each client navigates to the URL and renders the corresponding state

The server also caches the last-pushed route in a ConsoleUiState struct so CLI query commands can read it.

Acceptance criteria:
- Server holds a ConsoleUiState struct containing: focused_issue_id, view_mode, search_query
- On receiving a state-changing notification (IssueFocused, ClearFocus, SetViewMode, SetSearch), the server constructs a URL route and pushes it via SSE
- The frontend navigates to the pushed URL -- this is the only mechanism for server-to-client state changes
- Two browser tabs opened simultaneously both navigate to the same URL after kbs console focus <id>
- No backwards-compatibility with the old fire-and-forget notification model

description:
The status key 'in_progress' is hard-coded in multiple places, making it impossible for projects to use custom status names.

The fix is to make status categories configurable (like Jira's status categories). Each status in the workflow config maps to one of a fixed set of categories: 'todo', 'in_progress', and 'done'. Business logic that currently hard-codes the string 'in_progress' (e.g. kbs update --claim, Jira sync, beads import, display color logic) instead looks up which configured status belongs to the 'in_progress' category.

Hard-coded locations to fix:
- rust/src/issue_update.rs: --claim hardcodes target status as "in_progress"
- rust/src/config.rs: default workflow/status definitions hard-code "in_progress" as a key
- rust/src/migration.rs: beads import maps "in-progress" to "in_progress" as a fixed canonical name
- rust/src/jira_sync.rs: Jira status mapping hardcodes "in_progress" as the target for in-progress-like statuses
- rust/src/issue_display.rs, issue_line.rs: color/display logic hard-codes "in_progress"

Approach:
- Add a 'category' field to StatusDefinition in ProjectConfiguration (values: 'todo', 'in_progress', 'done')
- Default config assigns categories to its built-in statuses
- Business logic resolves the active status by finding the first status with category 'in_progress'
- Beads and Jira imports map to category rather than a hard-coded key
title: Status categories should be configurable; status names should not be magic strings

description:
Given the console server is running
And a CLI command previously pushed a route (e.g., kbs console focus tskl-abc)

When a new browser tab opens the console at the base URL (no deep link in the URL)

Then the server replays the last-pushed route as an SSE event on the realtime channel
And the browser navigates to that route
And the UI renders the same state as all other connected clients

If no route has been pushed since server start, the browser shows the default board.

Acceptance criteria:
- On SSE connection, the server replays the last route-push event to the new subscriber
- The frontend handles this the same as any other SSE route-push (navigates to the URL)
- No special endpoint needed -- uses the existing SSE realtime channel

description:
Given an agent has added a comment to an issue

When the agent runs kbs console focus tskl-abc --comment 8ea9cd

Then the CLI sends a notification through the server
And the server pushes a URL route to all connected clients: /issues/tskl-abc?focused=tskl-abc&comment=8ea9cd
And the browser navigates to that URL
And the detail panel opens to the issue
And the panel scrolls to the specified comment
And the comment is visually highlighted

Given a user opens a URL with a comment parameter directly in their browser

When the URL contains ?comment=8ea9cd

Then the same scroll-to and highlight behavior occurs

This extends the URL-as-state model to sub-issue elements. The comment parameter is the first
such element but the pattern should support future element types (e.g., a specific field change).

Acceptance criteria:
- kbs console focus accepts an optional --comment <id> flag
- Comment ID is encoded as ?comment=<id> query parameter in the URL
- Frontend parses ?comment= on load and on SSE-pushed route changes
- Detail panel scrolls to the comment and highlights it (existing highlight animation can be reused)
- Works on initial page load (pasting URL) and on SSE push (agent workflow)
title: Deep link to specific comment within an issue via URL and CLI

description:
As a backend engineer, I want every issue create/update/delete/state-change/comment action to emit a single JSON event file in project/events/ named with the ISO8601 timestamp, so that the system has an append-only, time-ordered log without relying on filesystem mtimes.

Acceptance Criteria:
- Event types at minimum: issue_created, state_transition, comment_added, field_updated, issue_deleted.
- Each file contains: event_id, issue_id, event_type, occurred_at (ISO8601), actor_id, and a payload specific to the type (e.g., from_state/to_state; comment_id; changed_fields).
- Exactly one file per event; no batching; no alternate storage.

description: Package kbsc as a VSCode extension so that developers can view the Kanbus kanban board for the current project directly inside VSCode, without leaving the editor. The extension spawns kbsc as a child process for the API backend, and loads the existing compiled React console app in a VSCode Webview panel. No changes to the existing React app are required  API calls are redirected via fetch/EventSource patching injected into the Webview.
title: VSCode Extension for Kanbus Board

description: As a developer working in a Kanbus project, I want the extension to activate automatically so that I can open the board without manual setup.  Acceptance Criteria (BDD):  Scenario: Extension activates when .kanbus.yml is present   Given a VSCode workspace containing a .kanbus.yml file   When VSCode opens the workspace   Then the extension activates   And the command 'Kanbus: Open Board' appears in the command palette  Scenario: Extension stays dormant in non-Kanbus workspaces   Given a VSCode workspace with no .kanbus.yml file   When VSCode opens the workspace   Then the extension does not activate   And 'Kanbus: Open Board' does not appear in the command palette  Implementation: Create apps/vscode/ with package.json (activationEvents: workspaceContains:.kanbus.yml), tsconfig.json, and src/extension.ts entry point registering the kanbus.openBoard command.
title: Extension activates in Kanbus projects

description: As a developer, I want the extension to manage the kbsc server lifecycle automatically so that I don't have to start it manually.  Acceptance Criteria (BDD):  Scenario: Server starts when the board is opened   Given the extension is active in a Kanbus workspace   And kbsc is not currently running for this workspace   When I run the 'Kanbus: Open Board' command   Then the extension finds a free port   And spawns kbsc as a child process with CONSOLE_PORT set to that port   And waits for 'Console backend listening on http://127.0.0.1:{port}' on stdout   And shows a progress notification while starting  Scenario: Server stops when the extension deactivates   Given kbsc is running as a child process of the extension   When I close VSCode or deactivate the extension   Then the kbsc process receives SIGTERM   And the port is released  Scenario: kbsc binary is not found   Given kbsc is not on PATH   And kanbus.kbscPath is not configured   When I run 'Kanbus: Open Board'   Then I see an error message explaining how to install kbsc or set the path  Scenario: User configures a custom kbsc path   Given kanbus.kbscPath is set to '/opt/kanbus/kbsc'   When I run 'Kanbus: Open Board'   Then the extension spawns '/opt/kanbus/kbsc' instead of looking on PATH  Implementation: Create src/kbscProcess.ts. Auto-select free port via net.createServer().listen(0). Parse port from kbsc stdout (console_local.rs:245). Set cwd to workspace folder so kbsc finds .kanbus.yml automatically.
title: kbsc server starts and stops with the extension

description: As a developer, I want to see my Kanbus kanban board inside a VSCode tab so that I can view my project's issues without switching to a browser.  Acceptance Criteria (BDD):  Scenario: Board opens in a Webview panel   Given the kbsc server is running on a free port   When I run 'Kanbus: Open Board'   Then a new VSCode tab opens titled 'Kanbus Board'   And the compiled React console app renders inside the tab   And I see kanban columns matching my project's configured statuses   And issue cards appear in the correct columns  Scenario: Board state is preserved when tab is hidden   Given the Kanbus Board tab is open and showing issues   When I switch to another tab and then switch back   Then the board is still rendered with the same scroll position and state   Because retainContextWhenHidden is enabled  Scenario: Re-running the command reveals existing panel   Given the Kanbus Board tab is already open   When I run 'Kanbus: Open Board' again   Then the existing tab is focused   And no second panel is created  Implementation: Create src/KanbusBoardPanel.ts. Read console-assets/index.html, rewrite /assets/* paths to webview.asWebviewUri() pointing to bundled console-assets/assets/. Set enableScripts: true, retainContextWhenHidden: true, localResourceRoots: [console-assets/].
title: Kanban board renders in a VSCode Webview panel

description: As a developer, I want the board to load live data and receive real-time updates so that I see the current state of my issues and changes appear automatically.  Acceptance Criteria (BDD):  Scenario: React app fetches data from kbsc   Given the Webview is loaded with the React console app   And kbsc is running on port 5200   When the React app calls fetch('/api/config') and fetch('/api/issues')   Then the injected fetch patch rewrites these to http://127.0.0.1:5200/api/config and /api/issues   And the board populates with the project configuration and issues  Scenario: SSE stream delivers real-time updates   Given the board is displayed in the Webview   And the React app opens new EventSource('/api/events')   Then the injected EventSource patch rewrites this to http://127.0.0.1:5200/api/events   And when an issue is created or updated via the CLI   Then the board updates automatically without a manual refresh  Scenario: Notification events reach the board   Given the board is displayed   When I run 'kbs create' or 'kbs update' from the terminal   Then kbsc receives the notification via Unix socket   And broadcasts it over the /api/events/realtime SSE stream   And the React app shows the new or updated issue  Scenario: Content Security Policy allows API connections   Given the Webview has a CSP meta tag   Then connect-src includes http://127.0.0.1:{PORT}   And script-src allows the nonce for the injected patch script   And style-src allows inline styles and Google Fonts  Implementation: Inject a script into the Webview HTML that patches window.fetch and window.EventSource. Also stub history.pushState/replaceState since Webview navigation is a no-op. Set CSP connect-src to the kbsc server URL.
title: API calls and real-time updates work inside the Webview

description: As a developer, I want the kanban board to match my VSCode color theme so that the board does not clash with my editor appearance.  Acceptance Criteria (BDD):  Scenario: Board uses dark theme when VSCode is in dark mode   Given VSCode is using a dark color theme   When I open the Kanbus Board   Then the board renders with dark background and light text   Because the injected script reads vscodeThemeKind and sets the 'dark' class on the html element  Scenario: Board uses light theme when VSCode is in light mode   Given VSCode is using a light color theme   When I open the Kanbus Board   Then the board renders with light background and dark text  Scenario: Board switches theme when VSCode theme changes   Given the Kanbus Board is open in dark mode   When I switch VSCode to a light theme   Then the board re-renders in light mode automatically   Because a MutationObserver watches for changes to data-vscode-theme-kind  Implementation: Add theme sync logic to the injected script in KanbusBoardPanel.ts. Read document.body.dataset.vscodeThemeKind, set dark/light class on html, observe mutations on the body attribute.

description: As a developer, I want to install the extension from a .vsix file so that I can use it without publishing to the VSCode Marketplace.  Acceptance Criteria (BDD):  Scenario: Console assets are bundled into the extension   Given the React console app has been built (apps/console/dist/ exists)   When I run 'npm run compile' in apps/vscode/   Then TypeScript source is compiled to apps/vscode/dist/   And apps/console/dist/ is copied to apps/vscode/console-assets/   And the extension can load the React app from console-assets/  Scenario: Extension packages as a .vsix file   Given the extension has been compiled   When I run 'npm run package' in apps/vscode/   Then a .vsix file is produced   And it contains dist/ and console-assets/ but not src/ or node_modules/  Scenario: Extension installs from .vsix   Given a kanbus-board-0.1.0.vsix file   When I run 'code --install-extension kanbus-board-0.1.0.vsix'   Then the extension installs   And activates in any workspace containing .kanbus.yml  Implementation: Add build scripts to package.json (compile: tsc + copy-assets, package: vsce package). Create .vscodeignore to exclude src/ and node_modules/. Add console-assets/ to .gitignore since it is a build artifact.
title: Extension builds and packages as a .vsix

description:
As a developer, I want to add local virtual project mappings in a gitignored .kanbus.override.yml file so that I can view issues from other local repositories on my board without committing those paths to the shared repository configuration.

The override file's virtual_projects entries are merged additively with those in .kanbus.yml so both sets of projects are available.
title: story Add .kanbus.override.yml support for local virtual project mappings

description:
Given the Kanbus VSCode extension .vsix is built by CI
When a release is tagged
Then the extension is published to the VSCode Marketplace automatically

Acceptance criteria:
- A 'kanbus' publisher account exists at marketplace.visualstudio.com
- An Azure DevOps Personal Access Token (PAT) is created with Marketplace → Manage scope and All accessible organizations
- The PAT is stored as the VSCE_PAT secret in the AnthusAI/Kanbus GitHub repository settings
- The release.yml vscode-extension job successfully publishes all platform .vsix files on tag push
- The extension appears publicly on the VSCode Marketplace at https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=kanbus.kanbus-board
title: Publish extension to VSCode Marketplace

description: load_project_directory() now derives the primary project directory from the config file rather than scanning all project directories. title: story CLI write commands work correctly when virtual projects are configured

description:
When the board is loaded using local asset serving (required for theme support), the webview shows a blank black page instead of rendering the kanban board.

Root cause: missing or incorrect Content-Security-Policy nonce. The injected patch script must carry the same nonce as declared in the CSP meta tag, and the CSP must allow scripts from the webview resource URI origin.

Acceptance criteria:
- Given the extension serves console-assets locally
- When the user runs Kanbus: Open Board
- Then the kanban board renders correctly (not blank)
- And the board respects VSCode light/dark theme
title: Blank page when serving assets locally for theme support
